comments.commentBody: Wow. Tortuous phrases. I had to say these aloud while my wife thought I'd gone 'round the bend to get some of the movie titles. I enjoyed this fine Sunday solve. Joel and Will should have pizza more often.

"If you want a rational alternative for questions of meaning and existential hopes and fears". Why want it? The universe is, it has no sense of of anything. There is no reasoning behind the existence of any one of us, unless you count "in vitro", or surrogacy, but even then which sperm fertilizes which ovum is still a random event. If we look at the biological imperative, our purpose is to leave a VIABLE next generation with the same imperative. Note in many nesting species the oldeer noffspring not only outcompee younger siblings for food, they often kill them.
We humans, with our profligate fecundity, and disregard for the environment, are misunderstanding this imperative, as "go forth and MULTIPLY!" I believe, it is, because of how hard it was previously, to multiply, we still have that ingrained cultural (not biologic, witness declining birthrates, in 'advanced' economies) tendency to our descendants' detriment.

Simple. If you want a rational alternative for questions of meaning and existential hopes and fears, read St. Thomas Aquinas. He builds on Aristotle and many others about questions of necessary versus contingent being, those who do not explain their own existence or the primordial issue of there being being in existence, act, potency, infinity, eternity.... Until then, this type of discourse is just a masqueraded attempt to undermine the inconvenient and its consequences, to replace true rationality and wonder with variable feelings and attitudes. Searching for rational truth and reasonableness is not a hobby or a pastime. So whether I feel cushy and satisfied or not is not the appropriate criterion. In fact, it is a disservice, as if my firm and cajoling belief that I can safely disregard gravity can be decisive.

Matt, you are dead wrong. You re-write history in the same way property owners rewrite slavery, as a benign, decent institution.

The evidence and facts do not support your view. The "decent and conservative" folk you idolize deliberately prevented African-Americans from participating in party primaries--the gateways to power. Those same folk prevented African-Americans from being delegates and party leaders, despite their overwhelming numbers. The Mississippi Freedom Party, organized by Ella Baker, Fannie Lou Hamer, and Robert Moses brought that to a head when they challenged the MS Democratic party's all-white delegation with a slate of 68 delegates in 1964.

By 1969, Lee Atwater, Harry Dent in SC (Atwater told me so!) urged Nixon to change positions on key issues to block political access to Southern blacks emerging from segregation to whom "decent" whites had denied jobs, fair wages, separated schools, denied admission to higher education, and threatened violence over public accommodations.

I live in the state and knew many of the people who helped organize the strategy you deny. It was an open secret even if no one kept records. The evidence is whites created a "new" party in which there was no power sharing or voices that reflected the tradition of gain-sharing Thurmond represented; paternalism hardened into racism.

Privately, old white Southern Republicans laugh at how well their propaganda worked and how you swallowed the bait. Privately, they tell the truth.
That would've been a nifty trick by Atwater, born in 1951 and only 18 at the time.

I voted Republican! For Strom Thurmond! It is amazing that Republicans and others persist in an egregious lie about Dr. King rather than use honest and real examples of blacks voting in large numbers independent of party.

The most recent case is in Mississippi, this summer when black voters crossed over in greater numbers than they had for the Democratic primary to defeat a Tea Party candidate in a run-off.

To perpetuate the lie about Dr. King's party-line votes also perpetuates the equally implausible myth that black voters are unable to determine their collective and self interests--and support these strategies with sophisticated organization and action.

On the issues of today, and Boehner, McConnell, et al. are not the party of Lincoln but the party of Nixon's southern strategy. To wit: Drawing false conclusions about history to dash real progress by eliminating Head Start, school nutrition, SNAP, and college loans, to shift the blame for racial violence, is the new danger. Cases of armed force against youth are increasing under the color of authority, by officials and citizens.

On audio, McConnell said if elected Senate majority leader, the Senate won’t even talk about raising the minimum wage, extending unemployment benefits and refinancing student debt.

“We’re not going to be debating these gosh-darn proposals. These people believe in all the wrong things.”

"Bottom line is that the euro is stronger than the dollar and appears set to remain so because if it weakens, the dollar will just be weakened further, faster."

This is incoherent.

Currencies are only more or less expensive relative to each other so if the Euro becomes "weaker" this probably, although not necessarily, means the dollar becomes more expensive AKA "stronger." If the Euro becomes less expensive than other currencies then Eurozone exports become more competitive in price, the current accounts of member nations improve and so also does their employment picture. This typically leads to a currency becoming more expensive and so the dance continues.

NB: Use of terms such as "weaker" and "stronger" for currencies has somehow taken hold but it is very misleading and can lead to bad policy choices; e.g., a "strong dollar" is generally not good for domestic employment even if does mean cheaper foreign goods and travel abroad.

A while back the Flying Spaghetti Monster was a popular rejoinder to literal Christianity.  A Flying Spaghetti Monster lived somewhere "up there" and held all sorts of wondrous powers.  The point being that this has just as much validity as walking on water and turning water into wine.  I think the problem with religion is that it is so often associated with such fantasy stories.  Yet how could anyone  not be drawn to the words (as opposed to the make-believe actions) of Jesus or Moses.  A college friend once told me that to her, God and love were the same thing.  I don't think science can explain either one.  Just think how much calmer and happier the world would be if more people believed that.

"The "death" of religion has been predicted or claimed numerous times over the centuries. It has never been true, and likely never will be."

You are probably right when we consider the major conflicts in the world.

Jews VS Muslims in the Middle East
Buddhists VS. Muslims in Myanmar
Hindi Vs. Muslims in India, Pakistan, etc., etc.
Orthodox Vs Eastern Catholics in the Ukraine
Etcetera, etcetera, etcetera!

You say, "Certainly, religion is dying." Actually, quite the reverse is true. In the U.S., while many are indeed "falling away" from "mainstream, organized, hierarchical" religion, this does not mean that they are no longer "religious," much less no longer "people of faith." Rather, many of those leaving "organized religion" are joining, or even forming, alternative churches, in homes, community rooms, etc. (Which is how the "church" started in the first place..) And globally, religion is, if anything, growing - particularly Christianity and Islam.

The "death" of religion has been predicted or claimed numerous times over the centuries. It has never been true, and likely never will be.

"Who invoked magic?
I missed that post..."

No, you repeatedly made that post. When you repeatedly make general claims about how slavery would have just ended somehow, people repeatedly point up specific details of how slaveowners were so unwilling to let that happen that they would use violence to dissolve the United States, and you completely ignore those points to make more totally unsupported vague claims about how it all would have worked out, you're pretty much invoking magic.

Slavery did not end in Brazil until 1889, and given that even with the Civil War, official Jim Crow continued into the 1960's, slavery would have continued in the CSA into the 20th century. Further, the CSA was determined to spread slavery into the West and the Caribbean. Mortality rates were already the highest for slaves in places like the Deep South sugar plantations. There's no way to know for sure, but it is entirely plausible that there would have been more slave deaths in Caribbean plantations and Western mines over the next 50-75 years than occurred in the Civil War. Lincoln had no option that did not result in a huge number of deaths. This is just in no way comparable to wars of choice and destructive military adventurism.

In defense of the economists who showed that slavery was a moribund institution (Time on the Cross, etc.) their conclusions always applied to the long run. By now, everyone who reads Krugman's columns and blog posts know what can be said for the long run and what Keyes said about all of us being dead in the long run. But the fascinating and important economic research into the role of slavery in the economy of the South still stands. One interpretation is that the Civil War was unnecessary, but that has always seemed attenuated. The other interpretation is that the leaders of the CSA and their supporters did not understand their economic interests or put their ideology ahead of their business interests. Given that interpretation, their willingness to go to war to protect slavery is still a mystery to me, but I am still confronted by the same mystery when I consider Red States electing Tea Party candidates who violate their economic interests.

"Peaceful solutions could have been found."

Perhaps, but then as now all attempts at compromise were rejected by one side or the other. Also, it was true then as it is today, that some things cannot be compromised; abhorrence of slavery is most certainly one of these.

When such issues are inevitably joined, there are no "alternative solutions" (to war) no matter how much anyone would wish otherwise. The issue, then, for the People's representatives and leaders, is to look inside themselves summoning all available wisdom and experience and instinct, in order to determine when it is proper to compromise and when it is not.

To preserve the union, make us a UNITED States and end the odious blight of slavery, Lincoln had no choice but to accept war. But how much better as a nation would we be without the South? Sure, bigotry would -- and has -- endured in the north and west, but slavery and it's direct descendant, apartheid, would unquestionably have survived in the South well into the late 20th century had they seceded. As a culture, the south maintains it's proud tradition of ignorance and anti- everything: evolution, climate change deniers, casual and endemic racism, and a virulent anti-government but where's my medicare/social security/disaster relief etc. welfare dependency. As a culture, has the South made any positive contributions to modern society?

I am shocked from some of the comments here that somehow, had the war not come, slavery would have magically disappeared. To enslave another human for even one more day is a crime against humanity -- then as now. The apologists should re-read Lincoln:

"Yet, if God wills that it continue until all the wealth piled by the bondsman’s two hundred and fifty years of unrequited toil shall be sunk, and until every drop of blood drawn with the lash shall be paid by another drawn with the sword, as was said three thousand years ago, so still it must be said “the judgments of the Lord are true and righteous altogether.”"

Joe: your answer is paternalism at its best! Thanks so much for speaking on behalf of the African-American community about its politics--while missing one of the community's main and most vital points for any of its historic firsts and pioneers. That principle (age-old!): "don't be sucked into conflicts, distracted by pettiness or blame; protect the gain; stay clean, do the job and function for all" (Travis Smiley and Cornell West notwithstanding).

From Frederick Douglass to Queen Mother Moore, blacks have understood when to put the gains first as a part of their interests, when to sacrifice and step back to protect the gain and to avoid overreach (or its appearance) which would destroy the gain and defeat the agenda and disrupt coalition building.

There is an old saw that "Religion is about laws, rules and behavior; faith is about a relationship with God."  It is because the "organized, mainstream, hierarchical" capital-C Church focuses more heavily on the former (i.e., dogma and doctrine) that so many are leaving it.  But this does not mean they have become "non-religious," much less no longer people of faith.  Rather, most of these people are joining (or forming) alternative churches, in homes, community spaces, etc.  And a majority of those alternative churches focus more on the latter - faith - than on the former.  Indeed, these newer churches have come to be called "Jesus" churches because they are more about Jesus' ministry - what he did and said - than about the laws, rituals, etc. that define organized religion.  And Jesus' ministry was based on 11 precepts: love, peace, forgiveness, compassion, humility, patience, charity, selflessness, service, justice and truth.  Not a bad underpinning for ANY faith or "spiritual" belief system - particularly when one learns to actually "practice what they preach."

When I read a story in the New York Times about the low approval ratings of the president, I always see one adjective used to describe it: "unpopular." This is false reporting and, I regret to say, cowardly.
Why cannot a reporter, or his/her editor, go for the jugular and report the truth: President Obama is hated in many of our 50 states; this hostility has little or nothing to do with domestic or international imperatives.
Ferguson is a mere outlier in the racial divide. Yes, we elected and re-elected a bi-racial president but he has not been granted the professional courtesy or the respect for his office--luxuries, as it were-- that no president before him could govern without. Mr. Obama had made his share of mistakes--but they are not the issue here.
The GOP, ably aided by a rogue elephant called the Tea Party, has succeeded in gumming up the federal bureaurocracy and has seduced an unenlightened electorate into assigning the blame to the president.
The public is weary and exhausted, ready to give up on their country; they seem to have capitulated to a dedicated minority who revel in dysfunction. Mr. Obama's poll numbers are poor? Reporters should ask the question, "Why," and not let go until they get at the truth.
President Obama is "unpopular?" Ask, "How so?"

Let me make sure I understand this. The Democrats are trying to mobilize a constituency that has given it anywhere from 85% to 96% of its vote every 4 years for the past half century while the Democrats have not won a simple majority of white male votes in the same time period.

Are these the same Democrats who handed the Republicans a gift in the senate in MS when they insured the 6 term unbeatable incumbent would win his primary (leading the Dem in the general by 16 points) over his tea party opponent (whom the Dem led in the general by one point)?

Rump, regional status, here come the Democrats!
